intro: Calycogonium bairdianum, commonly known as the golden cupplant, is a herbaceous perennial native to North America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its striking yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has a basal rosette of narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces tall, branching stems with numerous flower heads. Its botanical features include a fibrous root system and the ability to thrive in moist, well-drained soils. It is often found in wetlands and along stream banks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
